Ignore my steam playtime, i've played this for hundreds of hours back in the day.
-----------


Grand Theft Auto: Vice City, released in 2002. It was set in 1986 in Vice City (Fictional name for Miami Beach, Florida, i guess it's not hard to tell). A game that is still one of the greatest games of this era, in 2003 everyone was crazy about it. You can judge if this is a masterpiece or not by just looking at it's popularity even nowadays, how many games that are 11 years old are still played today? Not many.

The atmosphere you find in this game is perfect, your ears are delighted with great tracks from: Michael Jackson (Never liked him, but he had some great tracks), Megadeth, Anthrax, Cutting Crew, The Whispers, The Outfield, Bryan Adams, Iron Maiden, Loverboy, Slayer, Judas Priest, even Frankie goes to Hollywood, and the list goes on more of course.

The graphics were absolutely amazing at the time of release. Gameplay was, and still is great, the mechanics are friendly. You ave a variety of weapons to choose from when it comes to slaughtering random people on the street, including hookers and old ladies.
The cars you find in this game, are mostly sport ones, you also can find scooters and motorbikes.

You play as Tommy Vercetti, a mafia member that just got out of the prison. You are involved in a deal that gone wrong and you need to find the people who 'backstabbed' you'.

In my opinion, this is the greatest GTA game released, shame that GTA V kinda destroyed the actual GTA feeling. I would love to see a GTA: Vice City remake.

As for the technical stuff about this game. It works on Windows 8.1 flawlessly, without any compatibility options set, or any patch or modification. It recognizes new resolutions (1440x900 user here).

A perfect game that gave me hundreds hours of fun many years ago.

reviewText:
So you might be asking why review a game that originally came out in 2002/2003? Well to this day it is still my favorite game. Nothing has come close to beating it and i donâ€™t think anything ever will.

Thereâ€™s been a lot of controversy over the years about the Grand Theft Auto games, and their potential effects on children; so, this is probably a bad time to mention that I first played Vice City when I was quite young.
But onto why I love the game so much: itâ€™s probably a mixture of nostalgia and obsession. I believe that it would be in my top 5 games that Iâ€™ve spent the most time on (Iâ€™ve probably beaten it 12 times), and itâ€™s quite ultimately the game I am the most familiar with.

One of the more-objectively strong reasons why I love Vice City over the other GTA games is that Tommy Vercetti, as a main character, makes the most sense. Itâ€™s out of character for the majority of GTA characters to run around on a rampage. Vercetti is a sandpaper-rough, heartless shell of a man: he only wants to get the money back that was stolen from him, and heâ€™ll work with whoever he can to achieve his goals. Some people may see him as a bit of a shallow character, but Iâ€™d rather that over a bad-guy-turned-good, like a lot of the other main characters in the GTA series. It just makes no sense for Niko (from GTA IV) to mow down dozens of pedestrians, when a lot of his dialogue is about the horrors of war back in his homeland, and how he is coming to the US to make himself a new life. Plus he first appears wearing a light blue-green Hawaiian shirt i mean what is there not to love.

Much like the cast of characters, the story of Vice City worked so wonderfully because the developers threw it all against the backdrop of the nineteen eighties, which was in itself just a rip roaring time to be alive. At least thatâ€™s the impression one gets from games and television. You know, if you ignored the cold war, economic recession and the bad hairstyles. Vice City won in my eyes as it was a straight up gangster story. It certainly helped that it was basically a retelling of Scarface. If youâ€™re going to make an 80s gangster movie thereâ€™s no better source material.

Now onto the most-subjective reason why I love the game, even more so than pure nostalgia: the radio stations, or more specifically: V Rock. I still have the entire audio file of the station on my computer, and Iâ€™d listen to it separate from the game. I listen to it while iâ€™m driving around today so that must count for something.

V Rock is still for me the pinnacle of in game music. As someone who wasnâ€™t that into music in my younger days, I can thank V Rock for introducing me to the bands I would still be listening to today. 2 Minutes to Midnight by Iron Maiden, Bark at the Moon from Ozzy, â™¥â™¥â™¥ On Feel The Noize by Quiet Riot, Twisted Sister, Motley Crue and many more. Classic metal at its finest. It was also hosted by everyoneâ€™s favourite radio host Lazlow, of Chatterbox fame.

This isnâ€™t to say that Vice City is a perfect game, but then again I personally believe that a critical part of loving something is realising that itâ€™s not perfect, and being okay with its faults. The game has some pretty obtrusive shooting controls, because of the early lock-on mechanic. Itâ€™s the same sort of issue that the other PS2-era GTAs had. This makes the shooting parts of gameplay quite unnecessarily hard. Not that I dislike a hard game, but I want to at least feel as though I am in control when I am getting the crap shot out of my character.

To summarise, Vice City is a great combination of atmosphere, story, characters, and soundtrack. If youâ€™re only familiar with the Grand Theft Auto games with fancy graphics on current-gen consoles, then you really should give Vice City a try.

You can thank me later.

reviewText: Grand Theft Auto: Vice City is loosely modeled after Miami, Florida. You play as Tommy Vercetti, a Mafia hitman released from prison who returns to Vice City and builds a criminal empire. Grand Theft Auto: Vice City was my very first introduction into the GTA Series. Back in 2004 or 2005, I had just gotten the new PS3 with the emotion chip, so I was able to play most playstation 2 games. There was a lot of controversy around Vice City at the time for the graphic violence and hidden sex scenes and everyone was anticipating the release of San Andreas, so I picked it up to see what the fuss was about. I must have played this game for days on end, it was such a blast. If you love the GTA Series, this is worth playing through at least once.

reviewText:
My favorite game in the franchise. Instead of silent protagonist Claude, you are now playing as Tommy Vercetti, charismatic member of Italian Mafia, who gets out of prison after serving 15 years for multiple killings. Soon enough he gets involved in a drug deal gone wrong and determines to find out who was behind it while building his own criminal empire.

Setting is moved from cold streets of Liberty City to more relaxed Vice City which is based on Miami. References to 80's culture are numerous - disco music, pastel suits, styled cars. The American crack epidemic, drug trafficking and organized crime that followed it are heavily represented in the game, which also draws inspiration from many movies and tv series such as Miami Vice, Scarface, Carlito's Way, Godfather and many others. I will mention some examples:

Retired colonel from Central America and drug trafficker Juan Cortez - parody of Manuel Noriega, Panama dictator and major player in drug trafficking during 80's.

Drug baron Ricardo Diaz may be influenced by Frank Lopez, character from Scarface who happens to be played by late Robert Loggia who did voice acting for Ray Machowski, corrupt police officer in GTA 3. Diaz's mansion is very similar to Montana's from the same movie. Betrayal and the same clothes also add to the full picture. Interesting thing is that he is voiced by Luis GuzmÃ¡n who played Gonzalo RodrÃ­guez Gacha, drug trafficker and one of the leaders of the notorious MedellÃ­n Cartel in Netflix original series Narcos. Diaz's physical resemblance and temper to him are rather substantial.

Ken Rosenberg's appearance and behaviour are nearly identical to David Kleinfeld, who was played by Sean Penn in Carlito's Way.

Lance Vance is voiced by Philip Michael Thomas who played Ricardo Tubbs in Miami Vice, which heavily influenced Vice City.

Tommy Vercetti was inspired by Tony Montana from Scarface. Memorable shootout scene was also incorporated.
Last but not least there is Escobar International Airport, no need to say anything about that one.

Game introduces bikes which are way more fun to drive than standard cars and will probably become your first choice in exploring the city. Later you get access to helicopters which are easy to control and are much better solution when you need a quick way to certain place, or you just want better view of the city. Those who prefer adventures on the sea are not forgotten, you can also drive boats.
Major gangs in VC are Cubans, Haitians, Vice City Bikers and members of Forelli Crime Family. All of side activites from GTA 3 are also present here. Newly introduced are assets purchases. They include strip club, taxi company, film studio, dance club, printing works, car showroom, ice cream factory and boatyard. Each of them has a number of missions attached, and once all of them are complete a given property will begin generating an ongoing income.

There is nine radio stations in the game - on seven of them you will listen great collection of licensed music, while talk shows that contain lots of satire are on remaining two. Big step was made compared to previous title in quantity of material - there is over 10 hours of it compared to 3.5h in GTA 3.
Voice actors lineup and their performance is phenomenal; Ray Liotta, Tom Sizemore, Burt Reynolds, William Fichtner, Dennis Hopper and Danny Trejo are present among many others. One person that you certainly don't expect is porn actress Jenna Jameson, who gives voice to appropriately named character Candy Suxxx.

Like its predecessor, Vice City was given a lot of GOTY awards and achieved huge commercial success, over 20 million sold copies speaks for itself. I really liked main character, and hope that Rockstar will bring him and Vice City setting back in the future.

reviewText:
GTA Vice City, a game created by Rockstar North (Edinburgh, Scotland), which was released a year after the release of GTA III, on October 2002 for the PS2, and later ported to PC in May 2003.

This time around, the game was based in Vice City, which resembles Miami.

You are playing as Tony, a member of the Forelli Family, which is based in Liberty City. The Don decided to expand it's borders, so they give you a huge ton of money and send you to Vice City to make a deal. Unfortunately, you get ambushed. All the money is lost and now you have to find a way to pay them back.

GTA Vice City solved all the issues that the 3rd one had. They doubled the amount of vehicles[gta.wikia.com], songs in radio stations and weapons. They even added FLYABLE helicopters and a plane to the game.

The solves the issues with gangs being hostile towards you. For those that don't remember, 5 out of 7 gangs would be hostile towards you by the end of the game. It became really annoying considering that some gangs had shotguns which could blow up your car in 2 shots. Well, in Vice City, there would be only 1 gang that would be hostile to you.

They also added more game mechanics. Now you could damage cars with melee weapons, shoot the tires(the cops would even have spiked strips during chases), and now you are able to shoot through windows of a car, giving you the ability to kill the driver.

They added the ability to wear outfits. (some areas, like the police station can only be accessed with such uniform)

They added motorcycles.

They added assets and safehouses which can be bought. Assets would have a set of missions that if you complete, you would get profit from. Safehouses would allows you to save your game and store additional cars in the garage. GTA III had only 3 safehouses, which are unlocked as you progress through the story. Well in Vice City, you get 9.

As i said, they added a few helicopters, and a plane that was actually flyable this time.

The amount of weapons increased, usually each weapon tier would allow you to pick from 3 weapons. But the biggest change was the addition of melee weapons. Unlike GTA III, where you only had a baseball bat, in Vice City you get to play with katanas, chainsaws, screwdrivers, mechettes, gold clubs etc...

They added a map

They added the ability to crouch. Now most of the time i see some one playing older GTAs, most of them never use that mechanic. Well, let me clear things out for you. Most objects in GTA, even cars, are made that way, so that when the player crouches, it fully covers him. But when you are starting the firing animation, your character will rise a bit above his cover. So in a way, this is kind of like the Gears of War cover system.
Now most people don't understand the importance of this mechanic. If you played GTA III, you probably know that there been like ~5 genuine shootouts in the game, the rest of the missions involved racing for the most part. Well, the crouching mechanic changed that, making at least 50% of game involving shootouts.

As always, the PC port suffers the same issues as in GTA III. Mouse problems and FPS locked to 30. Most glitches can be fixed with SilentPatch.

Do i recommend it?
Well, this is probably the only game that is set in the 80's period. The songs in the radio, the cars, the city itself, something makes it so special. This is definately a gem.

Other than that, this is the 2nd game of the GTA III era, which are all connected. And chronologically, plot wise, they are set in this order:
1986 - Vice City
1992 - San Andreas
2001 - GTA III

To prevent this from happening, Sonny ostensibly promotes Tommy to a capo and sends him to Vice City under the guardianship of a crooked lawyer and Sonny's contact Ken Rosenberg to act as their buyer for a series of cocaine deals for Sonny, whose interest is to expand his family activities down the South and to overrun the Liberty drug market with the high-end cocaine from Vice City, hoping to create a monopoly on the Liberty City drug ring to establish the Forelli Crime Family on the top.[5]

Soon, Tommy and his bodyguards are awaited at the Escobar International Airport by Ken, who gives them an info about the deal and takes them to the docks, where they are awaited by the Vance Crime Family, prominent drug kingpins of Vice City led by Victor Vance, who arrive in the chopper with Diaz. As they settle the deal, they are ambushed by several armed and masked men, who kill Victor and Tommy's bodyguards. Tommy narrowly escapes with Ken from the docks, and as a result, he ultimately loses both Forelli's money and the cocaine in the process. Ken drives to his office, while Tommy returns to his hotel.[6]

When Tommy informs Sonny of the ambush, Sonny loses his temper and threatens Tommy with the consequences of attempting to cheat the Mafia. Tommy promises to retrieve the money and the cocaine and kill whoever was responsible for the ambush.[7] Towards this end, Tommy meets up again with Ken at his office, who leads Tommy to retired Colonel and mid-level drug dealer named Juan Garcia Cortez, who was Victor Vance's contact and who organised the deal between the Vances and the Forellis. Cortez expresses regret about Tommy's bad deal and promises that his own lines of inquiry are being made to find out who masterminded the ambush plot. Tommy also meets Cortez's daughter Mercedes, who becomes Tommy's confidante shortly thereafter.

While Tommy waits for the outcome of Cortez's investigation, he meets cocky 21-year old British record producer Kent Paul, real estate mogul Avery Carrington, and a mysterious man, who introduces himself as Lance Vance, younger brother of Victor and the underboss of the now-defunct Vance Crime Family, who wants revenge for the death of his brother and also wants the Vance Crime Family back on the map.[8]

As time passes, Tommy befriends Cortez and begins to do regular work for him as an errand boy and hitman. On one such job, Tommy is called in with Lance to protect the deal of a drug baron named Ricardo Diaz during a deal with the Cubans, looking to buy some high-end cocaine. During the deal, Diaz is ambushed by a gang of Haitians, but Tommy is able to kill them and save the deal, as well as Diaz's life. Consequently, Diaz begins hiring Tommy for his own agenda. Tommy takes this work because it pays well, in spite of his distaste for Diaz. On another errand for Cortez, he plans to meet a French courier to retrieve missile chips stolen from the French government. Tommy learns from Cortez that Cortez's own lieutenant, Gonzalez, was partially responsible for the ambush on Tommy's cocaine deal since he is the only person besides Cortez to know about the deal, and Cortez asks Tommy to kill Gonzalez as a favour, since he was a man who he did distrust and was working behind his back. Afterwards, Cortez voices his suspicion that Diaz might have been behind the ambush. Tommy initially continues the status quo to prepare for his attack, but his hand is forced when Lance attempts to take revenge by himself and fails, forcing Tommy to rush across the city and rescue him from the junkyard in which he is held. With the die cast, the two move quickly to raid Diaz's mansion and execute Diaz. With Diaz dead, and Colonel Cortez fleeing the country to escape the French, the established drug empires in Vice City quickly crumble and Tommy and Lance personally take over, becoming Vice City's drug kingpins.

Tommy becomes the head of his own organisation, the Vercetti Crime Family, distancing himself from the Forelli Family and Liberty City and more interested in personally controlling Vice City than being Forelli's puppet. But the more powerful and rich Tommy gets, the more Lance begins to exhibit paranoia and sociopathic behaviours, to the point that he begins to abuse his own bodyguards and constantly calls Tommy in states of hysteria, losing his mind over being just a powerless second-in-command as he was under his brother for the past 2 years. Tommy begins to suspect that Lance is up to something.

Tommy makes alliance with Umberto Robina's Cubans against Auntie Poulet's Haitians, even though he is at the same time hypnotised by Poulet's voodoo into helping the Haitians as well. However, Tommy and Poulet part ways Tommy and the Cubans sneak explosives into the Haitian drug factory disguised in Haitian gang cars and blow it up, effectively ending the conflict and putting the Haitians out of business, enabling the Cubans to take over Little Havana. Umberto then becomes Tommy's partner. He also becomes friends with Big Mitch Baker, a leader of the biker gang and a Vietnam veteran, with both the bikers and the Cubans becoming protectors of Vercetti family business.

As his drug business expands, Tommy buys assets in nearly bankrupt companies such as a car lot named Sunshine Autos, a cab depot Kaufmann Cabs, a popular night club called The Malibu, a local boathouse, a print shop, Print Works, an ice-cream company, and an adult film company, all of which he turns back into competitive businesses. He also becomes a personal bodyguard to glam metal band Love Fist, and pulls a major bank heist. He starts to control almost all the assets and ties of Vice City: Sunshine Autos as a chop shop, Kaufmann Cabs for money laundering, The Malibu Club for dispatching drugs, the ice-cream company for the production of drugs and the film company to control the underground movie scene.

Eventually, the Forelli family discovers that Tommy has gained control over entire Vice City and without having sent a single dime back to them. Sonny is enraged that Tommy has become independent and is hustling him, and sends collectors consisting of high-ranking Forelli members to force money out of Tommy's assets. Tommy disposes of them, but after they injure the elderly operator of his print shop of counterfeit money, he decides to cut Sonny and the Forelli family out of his business, severing his ties with the Forelli family.

An angered Sonny arrives in Vice City with a small army of mafiosi, intent on taking their tribute by force. Sonny and his henchmen soon arrive at the Vercetti Estate. Just as Tommy attempts to give them their tribute in counterfeit money, Sonny reveals he is the one who set Tommy up fifteen years before, sending him to kill the eleven men who were expecting him since he was feeling that Tommy would himself take over Sonny's business. Lance then exposes himself as a traitor, revealing Tommy's attempt to fool Sonny, and also admitting to informing Sonny about Tommy's activities in Vice City. Lance explains that he did it because Tommy started to disown him and didn't treat him equally, and wanted him dead so he could rebuild the Vance Crime Family and the fortune he had with his brother. An enraged Tommy starts a gunfight.

In the ensuing battle, Tommy first chases, ridicules, and finally kills Lance, then storms downstairs, where he faces off with Sonny,

reviewText:
Having trouble with the game? Turn your frame limiter ON! It fixes about 8/10 of the common bugs.

Grand Theft Auto: Vice City

Vice City is a game from my younger years. I originally bought the game in a special edition set on a CD-disk. Along with a manual and a map of the Vice City. Though i never really got into the missions as a kid, i now decided to boot Vice City again and play the storyline on stream.

I can say that Vice City has it's good and bad moments. Good moments as in the gameplay, the story and that pure feeling. Bad moments as in the sometimes poor performance, the bugs and the glitches.

I was really caught into the story and have never inserted a single cheat. I spend more than 20+ hours on the game and managed to complete the game with all assets completed(which are side-missions) and had found 90/100 hidden packages. The hidden packages are rewarding and so are the missions. As you play you slowly become more powerful by the mission, yet you do quite some errands but fair is fair, most missions are uniqie, fun and challenging. Even though there is no difficulty,  I managed to struggle with the game for quite some times.

The most annoying thing i experienced was the fact that people and vehicles literally vanish or appear out of thin air if you turn around. Scary it was not, annoying it was. Park your car, walk into an alley... come back and 'poof' your car is gone.

Yet Rockstar is Rockstar and Rockstar wouldn't be Rockstar if they weren't adding easter eggs and those little secrets, mysteries and theories which just make me melt. During my game i have found quite some easter eggs. Not gonna share or spoil but trust me when i say that they are worth a chuckle and smile.

I have played the game without cheats or spoilers and managed to get and take the most out of the game.

I can happily recommend the game. It's one of the 'better' Grand Theft Auto games out there and is with that said quite a jewel. Just make sure you have your frame limiter turned on. It literally affects everything. Handling, the speed of vehicles (especially ships ) and much more.

Oh and the music is gold. It will help you get that feeling i mentioned earlier!

First of all, use cheats, otherwise you will run out of money buying armour and weapons all the time.
Also, as it is an old game, there is no load option in the pause menu. You have to drive to your home to save or load a game, which can get frustrating every time you die or get arrested and want to save money by not spending it again on weapons and armour.

The graphics are average, it is an old game so we will let that pass. The physics, however, are absolutely horrible, you fall immediately off a motorcycle from the slightest of touches; using planes and helicopters are a drag, and some cars are just impossible to drive with.

OK, the game. Tommy Vercetti is your lead character, and he's come to Vice City to take it over. You do missions for various gangs, businesses, and mafia type bosses.

Overall, I'll give this a 7/10

reviewText: This is one of the, if not the, best games in the series. It's my first GTA game and it's damn awesome. It sets a perfect mood of the 80's with the music, the cars, and other things. The map is decent in size and I still seem to find something fun to do everytime I put the game on. The story is OK, but most people only play this game to mess around in the sandbox (like me). You can buy properties after you finish the career, and some of them can generate money. reviewText:
Short version: 92%GTA: Vice City is probably the goofiest, yet most timeless entry in the GTA series. Bright colours, fast cars, nonsensical missions, funny characters, and great controls made sure that this game is still regarded by many as their favourite in the franchise.

Long version:Grand Theft Auto: Vice City is a strange one, even for GTA. The whole game is more or less an 18-hour parody of Miami Viceâ€“ a half-forgotten, enjoyably dumb action show of the 80s. Everything is colourful and neon bright, and practically every story mission, every character, every random dialogue is a parody of something (just listen to the two talk show radios; they are full of the weirdest things).

What makes it a masterpiece is that none of these are over the top. The storyline may be silly at some points, but the core of it is deadly serious: you play as a gangster who was sent to Vice City (Miami) to create a foothold for the Mafia drug business. The deal goes belly-up, but by the end of the game you somehow become the de facto crime lord of the city, either by buying or killing any opposition.

The missions that lead to this goal have great variety and design; almost none feel the same and everyone can find their favourites among them. To complete them, you have access to a wider variety of weapons and vehicles, which now include aircraft and motorcycles. Travelling around is quite easy and fun now.
Many old-school game elements like bomb shops and the top-down camera were removed, but they are rarely missed with such improvements as purchasable assets, which all can be turned into a money-making machine after you complete their associated tasks. Although you still cannot spend that money on anything but more assets and weapons.

These smaller and larger touches not only made Vice City a great game, but also probably the most characteristic and memorable one in the GTA franchise, earning it a permanent spot in many of the playersâ€™ hearts.

reviewText:
While it may be a far cry from San Andreas or Modern GTA games in terms of content, I'd say this one is my personal favorite for its atmosphere, characters, setting, soundtrack, easter eggs, and nostalgic value. With 1980's charm pouring out of its â™¥â™¥â™¥, it makes of a unique entry in the series, being riddled with several nods and references to events, and Movies/TV shows (notably Miami Vice and Scarface). The gameplay is your run-in-the-mill post-GTA III formula a.k.a a free-roam sandbox. You go on missions to kill people while protecting and optionally developing your own dirty business that will eventually pay for itself to eventually achieve vengeance. While the story is linear, being a sandbox game, you have plenty of freedom. In addition, you have several sidequests, such as Vigilante and Ambulance mission, or item collecting, with worthwhile rewards, like increased Max Health or Missile-Firing Choppers. The game supports both Keyboard+Mouse and Gamepad modes, which puts this game ahead of its time in this particular aspect.

The cons are fairly simple fixes. Being a pre-HD era game, the game isn't optimized for Widescreen monitors, and while there is an in-game option for Widescreen, it steches the HUD and just crops the top and bottom. This can be fixed either by playing it in 4:3, or via simple mods for true, uncropped/unstretched Widescreen. Another issue that may affect most modern rigs is that you may have trouble getting the game to run. This again can be fixed through simple tweaks.

If you're gonna get into the GTA games and don't mind playing something that's only a decade old, this entry is definitely one that shouldn't be overlooked.

reviewText:
GTA Vice City - A true, timeless masterpiece, that has endured the test of time and is still one of the best games in the series.

Just like all older games, this one does not strike you with stunning visuals, like the newer additions in the series like GTA IV and V. But graphics is not all about a game. GTA Vice City offers a great story, characters and the feeling of freedom in its beautiful open-world city, that only few other games manage to capture.

The refferences to the pop culture of the 80s are to be found literaly everywhere in Vice City, which accomplishes the atmosphere of the 80s' Miami, which the game aims to recreate in its own unique style.  The style of the people that you see in the streets, the cars, the buildings' architecture and the scenery all help you immerse with the game and makes you feel as if you are watching a movie, rather than playing a game.

The soundtrack that Rockstar have compiled is divine, topping even those from the newer entries in the GTA series. All the radio stations in the game are absolutely fantastic with songs from the titans of the 80s' musical scene like Michael Jackson, Ozzy Osbourne, Mr. Mister, Toto, INXS, Laura Brannigan and many others. Even if you don't like this kind of music, the game will make you fall in love with it. But there's more - the radio stations' DJs will make you laugh all the time with their comments on topics that satirize different aspects of the life in the 80s. And the commercials too!

The story of the game is also brilliant. As if it is directly taken from a classical gangster movie. Filled with action, twists and many great characters you will be thrilled from the start and until the very end. But even after the completion of all the story missions you will have to spend many more hours if you want to unlock 100% of the game. The game will offer you more than at least 20 hours of sheer fun, but no doubt you will want to come back again and play it over and over again. But if you don't like playing by the rules, you will still be able to find lots of fun things to do. Steal a car, go on a rampage, attain a six-star wamted level and have some fun blowing up police and military vehicles and shooting SWAT teams with tons of great weapons, as they try to stop you.

More than 10 years after its initial release GTA Vice City is still the excellent game it used to be. If you have not had the chance to play the game until now, do not hesitate and get it right away.

%100'ed this game in approx. 60 hours. So I know a lot of things about this game.

Cons:

- The game itself is unbalanced! You can die in 2 or 3 seconds if you are under enemy attack.
- You'll come to a point where you'll need a lot of money. Yes, you'll stuck for having small amount of money...

And also, %100 of this game is hard. Yep, this is really hard. This was harder than San Andreas for me.

reviewText:
The 'Best' GTA game. It is the best GTA due to it's design.
The concept is simple. Open world and there are missions. The missions introduce you to new features in the game, or you can explore and find them yourself. San Andreas has the same design but the expanded world does not accommodate the game feel. San Andreas, GTA 4 and GTA 5 all have bigger open worlds than Vice City and therefore more to do in a sense (more time to waste). As a game, Vice City is the perfect GTA. Because, the open world is big, but not big enough for you to lose your way. Vice City is more simple and therefore better as a game. I never found myself wasting my time in Vice City. In San Andreas, GTa 4 and 5, myself and even you, always find yourself drivng around aimlessly, killing random people...sure this can be ammusing at the very least, but it won't compel you to keep playing the game. Vice City is a smaller game in scale and therefore the games design works.

75/100

I played it on PC way back as well as on PS2 (mainly PS2), but I was too young to really remember too much. I really prefer it to all the newer GTA games and would play this over any other game in my Steam library, but I'm really biased since it was probably the first game I ever played.
If you haven't played this game before, you have to get it; just not for PC. It seems really broken, which would be fine if it was only visually. It's just a ton of game breaking stuff that holds it back:

- Alt tab out and you lose the ability to rotate the player with your mouse (which... is pretty essential) until you go into your settings and toggle around a bit
- Motorbikes wobble
- Game seems to crash (just a black screen, not an actual crash) after starting a mission (which is why I'm writing this review rather than playing it)


The sad thing is that I only actually got 27% though the game before, despite putting a lot of time into it. I was young, car races turned me away from the game - too hard. I'm sure it'd be an easy victory for me now.


Overall: 110% recommend. Oh, and the radio music.

If you cannot run this game, you should install a dual boot to a supported OS or something.

I ran into a small issue with controllers, but I quickly found a nice solution on the forums, and the controller is working correctly now.

My biggest reason to suggest a buy?

Plenty of laptops will run this.  The hardware needs are trivial compared to todays machines.  I look for games that don't cost too much, and would play well on a variety of my machines, as well as allowing the possibility to add mods that would push the engine further.

Plenty of PS2 era games are still amazing, and have that nice bonus of being playable on even low end setups (usually... god help you if your rig is less than this :/ )

I digress, if you see this on sale, snatch it up.  I personally prefer this to SA, but SA has the land and the vehicles, so it wins every time.  The feel of Vice City is a much better game to me though.

reviewText: For many people Vice City is still the best GTA game today. I personally prefer San Andreas, but there's no doubt that Vice City is a masterpiece, surpassing San Andreas in both the setting (80's Miami) and music (fitting this setting nicely). Vice City improved on GTA III by adding a nice story with a better protagonist and side characters, expanding the soundtrack, improving the shooting mechanics, adding motorbikes and helicopters (now you have a Hunter to cause chaos alongside the Rhino) and a lot more side content with more rewards. It's also easier, meaning that you can have a good time for longer without dying or getting busted. The map also feels more well designed and consistent, and the mission variety is also nice. In the end, Vice City was and still is a brilliant game, among other GTA's and on it's own.\n\nAgain, i recommend you to install at least SilentPatch fo fix bugs and issues, and the Widescreen Fix if you use a widescreen and GInput if you wish to play it with a controller.

reviewText: This is the first GTA game I actually ever played, though it's my second favorite in the series. Second only from the length of gameplay though does it fall behind San Andreas, excluding that it has the best campaign of any GTA I've ever played. I remember when it came out that my desktop could barely run it maxed and now my laptop maxes it out with an Intel HD 3000. I decided to mod it up to modern expectations and after many google searches and overhauls I settled on Vice Cry as a base for expansion. Vice Cry tripled the view distance, replaced the meshes for the cars with the xbox versions (higher detail), applied a wide screen and resolution fix, and many other little things. It doesn't replace the Ginput system with the Xinput system (for 360 and PS3 controllers) but there were many guides to replacing it in the community guides that I found in a few seconds. If you can't get your mods running just use the old no-cd patch, name it gta-vc.exe, and Steam will run it fine allowing CLEO and dependent mods to run. reviewText:
The second GTA game i played back in the day. Vice City came out on the PC in 2003, i picked it up and played it somewhere around 2005 to 2007. Quite possibly my favorite GTA of all time. Im a sucker for anything 80's so that further heightened the experience of this game. If you haven't played this one i would highly recommened playing it.

The story is more intereresting than GTA 3 imo; it takes alot of cues from 80's films, and television. The aesthetics of the world really work in its favor and really makes you feel like your in the 80's. The various car designs, the npcs, and even the many easteregg references (Scarface mansion, Miami Vice music and cops) really addon to it.

The gameplay is still the same from its predecessor. You have the ability to jump, run, sprint and crouch like GTA 3. There are new weapons in this GTA; compared to GTA3 having one set of weapons, GTA Vice City has atleast 4 sets of weapons from small to heavy.

For the music you have yet again a really well picked soundtrack. You have a combination of 80's hip hop to Rock, to Newwave and Synthpop. The sound effects were well made for its time. As for the voice acting you have a couple of celebrities (Ray Liotta as Tommy Vercetti) Dennis Hopper, Burt Reynolds, Gary busey etc essentially a top notch performance and an interesting choice to have them voice the characters given their backgrounds.

All in all, its well worth the money and its another great GTA experience.

reviewText:
One of the best GTA games second only to San Andreas imo.

Considering it used the same engine as GTA 3, Rockstar really polished the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ outta this game by improving pretty much everything mechanics wise, like the cars longer being insanely dangerous to drive, better gunplay, flying, etc. It also introduced cool little things that are still present in current GTAs like buying properties.

Vice City excels in atmosphere above anything else. Nothing like driving down Washington Beach at night listening to Flash fm to make you feel immersed. The graphics are very stylish with pretty lighting effects specially prominent at night. It also helps that the game has amazing radio stations that also give a bit of backstory to recurring radio stars in the franchise, like Laslow. Vice City feels very alive.

Plot pretty much feels like a tribute to Scarface, this is clearly visible in the last mission. There's references to Carlito's Way and Miami Vice. The story features memorable characters and awesome moments with one of the best protagonists in the franchise. Tommy Vercetti is a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing boss.

I hope the next GTA takes us back to a remastered Vice City in the HD universe.

reviewText: The best GTA game, hands down. Well, unless V is good but after IV.. Anyhow, the game is great, it's funny, it's got a PERFECT 80's atmosphere, with probably the most kickass soundtrack in a game. The radio has some witty banter, but the music is the best part. The graphics are a little aged but you can install some graphical mods if you're willing to learn a little bit about modding. The game is best played with a controller, but otherwise, it's Grand Theft Auto, the story is the best out of all of them, it's got likable characters and movie references all around. Everyone says San Andreas and IV are the best, but I can tell you, anyone who has played Vice City will tell you different. Just give it a go, most modern computers can run it and it's pretty cheap. If you're a fan of the series, do NOT pass this up. No complaints besides maybe it could do with a little better kb+m support.  9.8/10.

**TO ALL WHO ARE HAVING MOUSE ISSUES WITH THIS GAME**
1. Run the game.
2. Start Task Manager (Ctrl+Alt+Delete).
3. Highlight the game then right click.
4. Click Go To Process".
(should take you to the "Processes" page with GTA already highlighted)
5. Right click the game and click on "Set Affinity".
6. Then it's going to ask you "Which Processors Are Allowed To Run?".
with the options to check on or off:
_<All Processors>
_CPU 0
_CPU 1
_CPU 2
_CPU 3
7. Check <All Processors> off and only check on one CPU
recommended: but I always just go with the first one: CPU 0.\n8. Click "OK" when chosen
hoursPlayed:
close the Task Manager and click back on the game and all should be well.
9. None of this will work if the game isn't already running before you open the Task Manager.

reviewText: Every now and then i buy an old classic that i missed at the time in the hope it will still kick â™¥â™¥â™¥ today. You win some, you lose some. I remember loving the ads for this game.
